STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 27, 2020
Jacquelyn Moffett
Homes for Black Children
1906 25th Street
Detroit, MI 48216-1440
RE: License #: CB820201177
Homes for Black Children
1906 25th Street
Detroit, MI 48216-1440
Dear Ms. Moffett:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
January 23, 2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MSA and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 Be signed and dated.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3012
Enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12203 Financial stability.
(1) An agency shall initially and annually develop and
implement a plan of financing for the operation of the
agency in carrying out its programs and meeting the
requirements for licensing. A plan of financing shall include
all of the following:
(e) An audit of all financial accounts conducted annually
by an independent certified public accountant not
administratively related to the agency. A copy of the audit
shall be available to the department upon request.
The agency has not completed an annual financial audit by an
independent certified public accountant not administratively
related to the agency.
R400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient
number of competent staff to carry out the provisions
covered by these rules. The workload for each staff
member shall not be more than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker
for purposes of providing direct services in foster
care, independent living, adoption, or post adoption
services or a combination thereof.
One of four foster care specialists had a caseload size of
sixteen. One above the fifteen children assigned that is
required.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
Two of three adoptive family evaluations reviewed were
completed untimely, one was completed on 4/30/19 and the
4

application was signed 11/12/2018 and one was completed on
1/10/2020 and the application was signed 2/26/201
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.49 Medical Passports updated:
Page 34
Medical passports shall be updated quarterly.
One of three open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation that the medical passport was updated quarterly.
The documentation did not show clear documentation that the
medical passport was provided to the required foster parent or
relative.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings:
FOM 722-6B -
page 2 -6
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home
cases: 30 calendar days before the service plan
• Case service plan development,
• permanency goal changes,
• placement preservation/disruption
• permanency planning at six months in care annual
transition
planning for youth every six months from age 16 until
case
closure,
• 90-day discharge planning for youth
• Case closure
5

One of three foster care records reviewed contained an FTM
after the report period. The report period was 3/12/2019 – 6/9/2019,
the FTM was completed on 6/13/2019, four days late.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM INTERIM 2019
DHHS Policy Dental Examination Schedule: Dental examinations are
FOM 801 required for children 3 years of age and older, as
Page 4 follows:
(2) An agency shall have documentation from the
medical or dental provider of all medical and
dental care received by a foster child.
One of three foster care records reviewed had no
documentation that the child had a dental examination.
DHHS Policy Follow -up Health Care
FOM – 801
Pages 8-9
The caseworker is responsible for reviewing the
information within the child’s Well Child Exam form,
the DHS -1664, Youth Health record, Dental form and
other medical, dental and mental health reports and/or
assessments. If follow-up medical or dental care or
mental health treatment is recommended, the
caseworker must ensure that the recommendations
are followed. Additionally, follow-up recommendations
received from emergency room or urgent care visits
require that the caseworker ensure treatment
recommendations are followed by the foster care
provider.
One of three foster care records reviewed, one had a follow
up dental appointment scheduled for 12/9/2019 so a spacer
could be put in the child’s mouth. There was no
documentation to support this appointment occurred.
6

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There was one incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The investigation resulted in corrective action plan in which the foster parent was to
demonstrate knowledge of appropriate behavior child management techniques. The
foster parent had to attend re-fresher in Pride training and sign a safety plan. The
agency’s actions were appropriate.
The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. The agency submitted a corrective action
plan for special investigation #2019C02002018 which was initiated on 3/8/2019.
The agency was in violation with PAFC 19-50001 regarding payments to a foster
parent. The agency was in the process of working on their corrective action plan
when special investigation #2019C0201021 was initiated on 5/8/2019. The
violations were PAFC 19-50001 and their financing and audit not being completed
timely. The agency is making foster care payments timely however, the agency
continue to struggle with getting their audit and financial accounts completed
annually by a certified public accountant.
The agency submitted a corrective action plan on 03/21/2019 interim inspection that
successfully addressed the following: R12312 foster parent training, ISEP 4.22
MiSACWIS (Commitment), DHHS Policy FOM 722 -6H Unannounced home visits,
DHHS Policy FOM SRM 200 Personnel training, DHHS Policy FOM 722-8C Foster
care parent agency treatment plan and service agreement. The agency has a
repeat violation with DHHS Policy FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting.
The 12/03/2019 analyst report was reviewed and follow up to safety issues and
concerns are as follows:
Safety and Concern Alert #1:
Concern:
Residence does not have an operable carbon monoxide dectector in the home.
Resolution:
7

On November 7, 2019 the foster parent purchased and installed a carbon
monoxide detector. A follow – up call was made to the foster parent and the foster
parent reported the detector was installed in the hallway between the two
bedrooms. A picture of this installed detector was forwarded to the Licensing
Supervisor. A home visit occurred on November 11, 2019 to physically verify
the carbon monoxide detector.
Safety and Concern Alert #2:
Concern:
No operable carbon monoxide dectector in the home.
Resolution:
The Licensing Specialist contacted the foster parent home on November 13, 2019
to notify her to purchase a carbon monoxide detector. The foster parent
purchased the carbon monoxide detector and on November 15, 2019, the
Licensing Specialist made a home visit and notice the carbon monoxide was
properly installed in the furnace/water heater room.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that Homes for Black Children
will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
01/27/2020

Pinkey Brown Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 28, 2020
